title-group.article-title: Determinants of long-term debt issuing decisions: An alternative approach

abstract.p: This paper proposes a probit model to test capital structure theories. Our model is designed to circumvent a methodological problem in traditional regression analysis stemming from the use of scaling (e.g., in the form of financial ratios) that has plagued capital structure studies for more than 100 years (Pearson, 1897). Without correction, this problem potentially yields a spurious relation between the dependent and explanatory variables. For example, a negative relationship between capital leverage and firm profitability is concluded in the literature, which is counter to what is observed in reality. Using a sample of leverage increasing cases resulting from public debt issuances in US markets between 1996 and 2006, our probit model results indicate that leverage increasing firms tend to be more profitable. Our finding is consistent with the fact that, in practice, more profitable firms usually have easier access to debt markets.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: A stream of capital structure empirical literature, using multiple regression models in a cross-sectional setting, attempts to find out whether ex ante firm characteristics affect managers’ financing decisions. In the models, accounting ratios are extensively used as explanatory variables to proxy for a firm’s characteristics (e.g., market-to-book ratio, profitability rate, etc.), with most studies using either current debt ratio or debt ratio changes (financial ratios or changes of ratios) as the dependent variable to proxy the result of any new financing decision. The dependent and independent variables share a common or correlated divisor(s) with a choice of size variable, such as the book/market value of total assets or sales to control for size effects. However, neither the use of scaling nor the use of leverage ratios (or ratio changes) as the dependent variable is trouble-free.

Using scaling in a multiple regression model may potentially lead to a spurious relation between the dependent and explanatory variables, as first noted by Pearson (1897). He shows that in the case where three uncorrelated identically distributed random variables X, Y, Z have the same coefficient of variation (standard deviation divided by expected value), the expected correlation coefficient estimator between Y/Z and X/Z is 0.5, when in fact the correlation between Y and X is 0. This contradictory result indicates that the coefficient estimators are biased in the model using ratios; hence, misleading inferences may be drawn. Kronmal (1993) further examines the spurious ratio problem and shows that the coefficient estimators are biased when ratios are used in dependent and independent variables. This confirms Lev and Sunder’s (1979) conclusion that the correlation between two variables (i.e., Y, X) is not equal to the correlation between their deflated variables (i.e., Y/Z, X/Z). A conventional statistical inference, such as t-statistics, fails to identify this spurious correlation if the model specification step is skipped. Thus, in order to apply t-statistics in multiple regression models, the normal distribution assumption for variable values has to be satisfied. However, Deakin (1976) and Frecka and Hopwood (1983) examine the cross-sectional distributional properties of the financial ratios values and find most of the ratios tend to depart from normality in their tests. In this regard, if ratios are the investigator’s interest, either the model or the statistical inference needs to be modified.

This study circumvents the spurious ratio problem by applying a probit model. Using a simulation technique developed by Barraclough (2007), we show in our model how ratios can be safely utilized to find firm characteristics impacting long-term debt issuance decisions. In addition, we make no further assumptions on the equity-debt substitute or target leverage ratio than those made by competing models. Therefore, our results are less likely to be prone to measurement errors, with the probit model being more appropriate as a means to investigate the financing decisions. In consequence, our model results are devoid of the spurious ratio problem and hence more reliable. For instance, our results indicate that leverage increasing firms tend to be more profitable(a significant positive relation between leverage and profitability), and this conclusion is consistent with what investors observe in credit markets. Firms with higher profitability are more attractive to lenders, which attributes to their better capability of paying back loans with retained earnings and prospective profits.

In past work, the evidence for a significant inverse relation between leverage and profitability has dominated the literature (e.g., Baker and Wurgler, 2002; Faulkender and Petersen, 2006; Rajan and Zingales, 1995; Titman and Wessels, 1988). Even the measures for profitability are slightly different across these studies: that is, those measures are ratios and used in multiple regression models without exception. Hence, they suffer from the same aforementioned spurious ratio problem. In this paper, however, the simulation results indicate our new model is not flawed even though ratios are used.

sec.title: 2. Literature review
sec.p: The milestone work on financing decisions is the irrelevance theory developed by Modigliani and Miller (1958), where they show that in a world without market frictions, no financing decision will change a firm’s value. Since then, numerous empirical studies have attempted to test if this conclusion still holds in a world with taxes and other frictions in both developed and emerging markets. Empirically, one most commonly adopted method is to perform a regression between a firm’s leverage ratio (book, market leverage or leverage differences) and measures of firm characteristics, such as assets tangibility, firm size, profitability, uniqueness and growth, to assess how these characteristics affect a firm’s financial leverage. In practice, these proxies along with debt are adjusted for size effects by scaling a choice of size variables (book, market value of total assets or sales). This adjustment is extensively used in capital structure literature; for instance, 39 factors commonly used in the previous studies are examined and ranked in Frank and Goyal’s (2003) study, and most of them are financial ratios. However, due to the contradictory results in previous studies,1 there is as yet no consensus on which explanatory variables are associated with financial leverages. Barraclough (2007) argues that the contradictory results are caused by a spurious ratio problem embedded in the multiple regression models using ratios. She also develops a simulation technique to give correct statistical inference when t-statistics fail at this point. Zhu (2012) uses this simulation technique and shows that once ratios are replaced by unscaled variables, the spurious ratio problem is evidenced. Therefore, using unscaled variables instead of ratios is one way to address this spurious ratio problem.

This paper approaches this problem by finding a different model (rather than multiple regression models) so that conventional t-statistics are still valid when ratios are used. Indeed, if ratios are the investigator’s interest, then using unscaled variables might be suboptimal to his/her research objective. We propose a probit model that is able to circumvent the spurious ratio problem while not compromising our research objective. In the capital structure literature, a number of studies model financing choices by using probit/logit methods,2 the main differences between these models being what the dichotomous variable responds to, and the assumptions made. In Marsh (1982), when the current debt ratio is lower than its target ratio, debt is issued and the dependent response variable is equal to 1; when the opposite occurs, equity is issued and, correspondingly, the response variable is set at 0. Since the target debt ratio is unobservable, Marsh uses the historical average as the target ratio as if the target ratio exists.

In contrast, the dichotomous variable in our model simply indicates whether debt is in fact issued or not. The benefits of doing so can be twofold. Firstly, the long-term debt is not assumed to be a perfect substitute of equity. In practice, the choice of securities, such as convertible bonds, short-term debt and dual issue, can be open. Secondly, it avoids assuming the existence of target capital structure. At a theoretical level, Modigliani and Miller (1958) suggest no target capital structure, but other studies, such as those by Fama and French (2002) and Flannery and Rangan (2006), propose target models of the leverage ratio. Their empirical results seems to indicate that the leverage ratio exhibits mean reversion and they treat the mean as evidence of a target ratio. However, Chang and Dasgupta (2009) extend the studies of Shyam-Sunder and Myers (1999) and Chen and Zhao (2007) to show that this mean reverting is not strong evidence of target ratios because, as they show, mean reverting can also occur in a simulated dataset even when, in fact, the financing behavior has no target (i.e., random).

Some survey data support that executives have an optimal debt ratio (e.g., Ang et al., 1997; Graham and Harvey, 2001). To date, however, these studies have been unable to answer some fundamental questions, such as: Do managers use the book leverage target or market leverage target? Is the target fixed or evolving over time? Given this, modeling debt issuances that have, in fact, occurred is unlikely to be prone to measurement errors or assumption fallacies.

Hovakimian (2004) uses logit models to test both the security issuance and retirement (e.g., repurchase). When a firm has cash surplus with a target capital structure in mind, the management chooses between retiring debt and repurchasing shares. Irrespective of which one is chosen, the retirement affects financial leverage, since its effect should be the opposite of that of the security issuance choice. They find more profitable firms tend to issue debt rather than equity and repurchase equity rather than retire debt. Similarly, Dittmar and Thakor (2007) predict that a manager’s decision depends on an investor’s sentiments about payoffs of the projects. Larger, more profitable firms are more likely to obtain funds from debt markets, as investors in debt markets prefer to lend money to less risky firms. Our results are consistent with their studies. In addition, we also show that firms with high research and development (R&D) expenditures are less likely to issue debt, which can be interpreted as these firms tending to be riskier due to higher bankruptcy risks.

Hovakimian et al. (2004) focus on the case of dual debt and equity issues, which are normally excluded from the sample in other studies. They suggest dual issuing firms can achieve a target capital structure at relatively lower costs compared to one-way issuing firms. Again, binary response models are used in the following scenarios: debt issue versus dual issue; dual issue versus equity issue; and debt issue versus equity issue. In the debt issue versus equity issue case, they find a positive profitability and size effect, and a negative R&D expenditure effect associated with debt issue decisions. These effects coincide with our results. Further, they find the profitability of debt issue is associated with negative growth (market-to-book ratio) and tangibility, whilst our results do not support such a relation.

sec.title: 3. Data
sec.p: Previous studies in this field are primarily empirical with a focus on developed countries, particularly on US markets. This paper also uses US data, not only because of the availability and completeness of that country’s data, but also to make the results comparable with the current literature. Even though the analysis is implemented using US data, audiences from other countries, such as Australia, may also be interested in these results given that there are high similarities in capital markets and business practices in both Australia and the US.

Some US studies include both public straight and convertible long-term debt issuing, resulting in larger sample sizes than the sample of public straight debt issuances only. However, earlier survey studies suggest that issuers generally regard convertible debt as a delayed equity offering (e.g., Brigham, 1966; Hoffmeister, 1977; Pilcher, 1955). Therefore, it is inappropriate to include convertible debt in the sample. In addition, several studies include both public and private long-term debt; however, the offering dates are not publicly ascertained for private debts, which weaken data reliability. Further, a number of studies focus on debt maturity by considering short- and long-term debts as substitutes, contrary to previous studies that examine the substitution effects between equity and debt.

This study focuses on leverage increases that are caused by public straight long-term debt issuances. In doing this, our research objective is better defined, although resulting in a smaller sample size. The sample inclusion is in line with our initiatives to compare our results to those of equity-debt substitute studies, while no assumption is required for setting the value of the binary variable based on the aforementioned reasons.

A number of data selection criteria are imposed. Firstly, we only include issuers of public straight debts with maturity of more than one year from the Securities Data Company (SDC Platinum) for the period 1996–2006. Secondly, firms without financial information on the Compustat or price information on the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) are excluded. Thirdly, firms in a regulated utility or a financial sector with the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) codes of 4900–4999 and 6000–6999 are excluded, since these firms are very different from their industry counterparts in terms of both assets structure and funding sources. Fourthly, firms with missing information on total assets, sales, shares outstanding and share price for the fiscal year end prior to debt offerings are deleted. Fifthly, to eliminate the possible impacts of other events within the firms, issuers with any of the following events occurring 30 calendar days before and after the announcement dates of debt offerings are excluded: ordinary share issue, convertible bond issue, stock split, share repurchase and mergers and acquisitions. Sixthly, companies with straight long-term debt offerings of more than once during the same fiscal year are excluded, because two consecutive debt announcements occurring in the same financial year makes it difficult to isolate the joint effect of these events. After imposing all the selection criteria, the final sample consists of 719 debt issue observations from 454 firms. The financial data required to measure our firm variables are obtained from the year-end financial statements prior to offerings, as it is reasonable to assume that managers make their financing decisions based on the previous year’s financial results.

Industry and size are used as matching dimensions in our study. Table 1 reports the distribution and size descriptive summary of debt issuing firms in terms of industry. About 40% of the total issuances fall into the following five industry categories: Chemicals, Communication, Food, Oil and Transportation equipment industries. In addition, these firms on average are sized at over US $3000 million in terms of total assets value.

sec.p: To employ the dichotomous probit model, a matching sample (e.g., ‘non-issuance’) is obtained using Barber and Lyon’s (1996) matching firm approach, where every issuance is matched with a ‘non-issuance’ (a firm without the debt issuance during the same year) according to its size and industry. Barber and Lyon claim that the matching method yields better specified test statistics than the factor models. Firms within the same industry are similar in their firm characteristics, given that they all face the same market and industry conditions, business operating risks, asset risks, etc. Bowen et al. (1982) and Bradley et al. (1984) suggest firms tend to retain their relative leverage ratio rankings within an industry over time.

Similar to Barber and Lyon (1996), who use the range of [70%, 130%] for size matching, the size of our control firm has a range of [60%, 140%] for a given candidate firm. Barber and Lyon employ a control firm that is the closest in size (when finding that a control firm within their size boundary is not possible). We, however, differ from this as we exclude these firms because we believe the closest size matching (outside the size boundary) creates potential selection errors. For instance, such a way of matching may result in a control firm having a much smaller size and the control firm under this situation may not have the same ability to access debt markets, compared with the candidate firm. This procedure reduces our sample size from 987 to 719 observations. Our industry match is defined as firms having the same first two-digit SIC code and size matching in terms of the book value of total assets.

Given two firms (a firm with debt issuance and its non-issuance matching firm) sharing analogous market conditions, assets structure, size and business risks, along with the fact that both can access debt markets, our research objective is to explore why they make different debt issuance decisions. The way we select a matching firm is motivated by attempts to investigate factors affecting a firm’s capital structure after controlling for industry and size. The selection process is as follows.

list-item.p: Step 1: We first merge the Compustat database with the CRSP database to ensure a smooth transition between financial and return data.
Step 2: The announcement information on long-term debt offerings is obtained from the SDC. Subsequently, the above three databases are merged together, which results in 1224 debt issuances remaining.
Step 3: Matches are obtained between issuing firms and their corresponding non-issuers.

Step 4: The debt issues with other ongoing events occurring within the event window of [−30, +30] are filtered out. There is no theoretical guidance on the choice of event window. Wider windows provide better alleviation of the possible influence of other events. However, our sample size is greatly reduced if a wider event window is used. Given the trade-off, a decision is made to favor the event window of [−30, +30], which results in 987 issuances.

sec.p: To match with a control firm in the same industry, the matching process mentioned above may have another problem. In some situations, for example, some firms may have several matches in a given year, while others may have a unique match, especially for the industries containing few public companies. To solve this problem, we first run the matching procedure mentioned above and obtain matching status for each sample firm for each year. Firms with only one match in a given year are highlighted (i.e., 156 cases). After that, the matching process is rerun with these firms granted a priority matching. The remaining firms are then subsequently matched. The procedure repeats 1500 times to ensure the duplicated control firms are minimized. Finally, the dichotomous variable is created with value of 1 for our sample firms and 0 for the control firms. Our final sample consists of 719 debt issuances from 454 firms and 719 non-issuance matches. We select five (four of them are financial ratios) of the 39 variables examined in Frank and Goyal (2003) that are classified as Tier 1 and Tier 2 robust factors.

sec.title: 4. Model and results
sec.p: We implement a probit model using the Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) method to detect the determinants of long-term debt issue decisions. This dichotomous variable indicates a firm’s financial choice of issuing debt or not. When the debt is issued, its value equals 1, and 0 otherwise, to present the probability of issuance. sec.p: To detect the spurious ratio problem, we adopt the simulation technique developed by Barraclough (2007) with a modification that allows the simulation to be used in the probit model. In the procedure, Y is now a dummy variable and is drawn from a binomial distribution of which 719 observations are valued at 0 and 719 are valued at 1.

Panel A of Table 3 presents cut-off values for the probit model. Firstly, the slope coefficient values are very close to zero compared with the results from the financial leverage models. In addition, the critical t-values are very close to conventional levels of [−1.96, +1.96], which suggests that even when ratios are used in the probit model, conventional statistical inference is still valid. Hence, in our probit model the spurious ratio problem documented by Barraclough (2007) is not evidenced. Further, the critical McFadden’s Pseudo R-squared value of 0.0058 is achieved at the 5% confidence level.

sec.p: Panel B of Table 3 reports the results of the probit model on the actual sample. Our simulation results suggest that conventional statistical inference is valid in probit models; it can be used free of the spurious ratio regression problem. The result suggests size and profitability measures are positively correlated to the likelihood of long-term debt issuance decisions, which imply larger, more profitable firms tend to use debt financing. The findings support the trade-off theory where larger firms prefer utilizing debts for tax benefit maximization purposes. This contradicts the prevalent evidence of an inverse relation between leverage and profitability. The size effect is also consistent with the empirical findings of Titman and Wessels (1988), Lemmon et al. (2008) and Faulkender and Petersen (2006), who find larger firms are more likely to access debt markets and issue 35% more debt than others.

The uniqueness measure (R&D/S) is shown to be negatively correlated with the probability of debt issuance. This finding is in line with previous findings (e.g., Faulkender and Petersen, 2006; Titman and Wessel, 1988) where firms with high R&D expenditures tend to be technology intensive companies and thus account for more intangible assets (or fewer tangible assets). In addition, the Pseudo R-squared (0.03) on the actual sample is greater than the critical value level (0.058), which suggests our model is significant at the equation level.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: This paper investigates the likelihood of long-term debt issuance in US markets over the period of 1996–2006. The probit model used in the study circumvents the spurious ratio problem evidenced in multiple regression models using ratios. With modification to the Monte Carlo simulation technique developed by Barraclough (2007), the critical values for slope coefficients, t-statistics and MacFadden’s Pseudo R-squared are generated for the probit model. Our simulation-based critical values are no different from conventional levels, which indicate no spurious ratio problem. By modeling the decision of debt issuance using a dichotomous variable, we find that, contrary to the stylized facts, our results suggest leverage increasing firms tend to be more profitable. Also, firms issuing public debt tend to be large in size, while firms with high R&D expenditures tend to be less likely to use debt as a means of financing.
